div.sent: They are given red-carpet receptions.
They are given welcome by waving small flags, colourful ribbons, by being presented bouquet of flowers and by decorating the Gate or Entrance.
By giving them such honour, a country expresses its goodwill.
It is a recognition of the guest's dignity and status.
The people of Jerusalem also welcomed our Lord Jesus Christ in the same way.
But unlike what is done for the State Guests today, there was no red carpet or bouquet of flowers, and no Gate was decorated.
There was no hoisting of the national flag or waving of colourful ribbons.
Jesus was born as a poor man in a stable in Bethlehem.
And he revealed himself as a humble and meek person.
And so he entered Jerusalem riding on a donkey.
And the people welcomed him by spreading their cloaks and branches from the trees on the road.
In this lesson we will learn about this in detail.
Jesus had been working many miracles among the people, and the news had spread far and wide.
Many used to gathered around him to hear him.
When Jesus was leaving Jericho, a large crowd was following.
On the way Jesus cured two blind men by touching their eyes.
They also followed Jesus to Jerusalem.
As Jesus, the Prince of Peace, with a large crowd following him, approached Jerusalem, they came to Bethphage at the Mount of Olives.
There Jesus sent two of his disciples on ahead with these instructions:
Untie them and bring them to me.
And if anyone says anything, tell him, The Master needs them; and then he will let them go at once.
So the disciples went and found the colt tied up, just as Jesus had told them.
As they were untying it, some of the bystanders stopped-them.
But when they were told that Jesus needed it, they let it go.
They brought the donkey and the colt to Jesus and spread their cloaks on the colt.
Jesus got on it and went towards Jerusalem.
When the people of Jerusalem heard that Jesus was coming to Jerusalem, they came forward and spread their cloacks on the-road to welcome him.
Some of them cut branches from the trees and spread them on the road.
The crowds walking in front of Jesus and those walking behind him began to shout in joy, Praise to David's son !
God bless him who comes in the name of the Lord !
Praise to God!
When Jesus entered Jerusalem, the whole city was thrown into an uproar.
The people asked, Who is he ?
To whom are they showing such great honour?
Those who knew him, they all gave testimony saying, This is the prophet Jesus, from Nazareth in Galilee.
Some of the Pharisees felt jealous and asked Jesus to tell them to be silent.
In answer Jesus said, I tell you that if they keep quiet, the stones themselves will start shouting.
The time will come when your enemies will destroy you.
Not a single stone will leave in its place, because you did not recognize the time when God came to save you!
Then Jesus went into the Temple.
A church or a temple is a place of worship and prayer.
But the merchants were doing business in the Temple, buying and selling their goods.
Jesus was very sad to see this and he was angry.
For they were desecrating the holy Temple.
But you have turned it into a hideout for thieves.
Every day Jesus taught in the Temple.
Many people who were lame and blind, came to Jesus in the Temple to be healed.
Jesus cured them all.
They began to conspire against Jesus in order to kill him.
Jesus went to Bethany to spend the night there.
Our Lord Jesus Christ lived in the family for thirty years and he was obedient to his parents.
His public life was only for three years.
He was not accorded a royal welcome like an earthly king or a President or a Prime Minister.
But the people recognized him as King from their hearts.
He entered Jerusalem in a humble way, riding on a donkey, as the Prince of Peace.
His Kingdom will be established in humility and love.
Therefore, he rode on an ordinary animal.
Instead of a red carpet, the people spread out their cloaks and some branches from the trees on the road.
We also see Jesus getting angry.
This anger can be explained by saying that Jesus wanted to respect the sacredness of the Temple.
Moreover, it is a matter of opposing injustice.
The priests and the teachers of the Law felt offended by Jesus behaviour.
For it was their responsibility to take care of the Temple.
No one could have carried on any business there without their permission.
But Jesus showed by his behaviour how just and conscientious he was.
So he wept thinking of the future of the Temple.
Our Lord Jesus Christ is the model of humility, love and justice.
Even though he is the King of kings, he accepted a simple public welcome.
He could have told his disciples to make some other arrangements, but he didn't.
Rather he preferred to ride on the colt of a donkey.
He did not choose a strong horse or a camel or an elephant to ride on.
The people showed him their respects by spreading branches of trees and their cloaks on the road.
This is a clear proof of Jesus, humility and meekness.
We observe this occasion even today, on Palm Sunday during the Season of Lent.
On that day, date- branches are brought into the church and blessed.
We proclaim Jesus as our King.
We must accept Christ as the shining example of humility, love and justice.
Christ himself has taught thsis to us.
No mastter how high our position in society is, we should be humble.
We have to love all people irrespective of their caste and creed.
Most of all, we have to shun the path of injustice and follow the path of justice.
By driving out the merchants from the Temple and over throwing their merchandise Jesus opposed injustice.
A house of prayer is a holy place.
It is not a place for any business.
If we make it to be so, then we desecrate it.
We should always remember this when we go to church, realizing that Christ is present there.
He is the King of heaven and earth.
We show great respect in many ways to our earthly kings or Presidents or Prime Ministers.
How much more should be our respect for Christ who is the King of kings.
We must show respect to someone who deserves our respect.
We must honour our respected elders, parents, teachers and religious leaders.
We must avoid evil, oppose injustice and practice justice.
We must show honour to great personalities and teach our young people to do the same.
All of us are familiar with the word supper.
It is a meal where there is arrangements for a variety of foods.
Such a meal is organized on the occasion of certain feasts or events.
For instance, on Christmas, Easter, Eid, Puja, wedding day or when there is a great achievement, a meal is organized.
Also, before our near relatives go away to a foreign country for a long time, we organize a meal in their honour.
Christmas, Easter, Eid, Puja, weddings are joyful occasions.
A farewell is normally painful, and yet a meal on this occasion expresses joy and good wishes.
A meal is organized on such occasions to invite the relatives to participate in it.
But a good meal requires a good preparation, so that everything goes well.
The place where the meal is organized is also cleaned up and decorated.
A menu is prepared for the meal.
Much care is taken so that there is enough for the number of invited guests.
All the arrangements are made with great care so that the celebrations go well.
Our Lord Jesus Christ arranged for such a farewell meal with his disciples.
In this lesson we will learn about this meal.
In the previous lesson you learned something about the Passover meal.
`Passover means passing over or deliverance.
Passover is celebrated in memory of the day on which God delivered his people, the Israelites, from the bondage of Egypt.
The Israelites were commanded to celebrate this festival from generation to generation.
Jesus Christ arranged to celebrate-this meal with his disciples before his death.
Through this meal was inaugurated the, new Passover to save mankind from the bondage of sin.
Preparation for the Passover Meal The Day of the Passover is called the Day of Unleavened Bread.
It is the day on which the paschal lamb was sacrificed.
The Apostles asked Jesus where they should arrange this meal.
Jesus sent Peter and John to make the arrangements for the meal.
Then he will show you a large upstairs room, prepared and furnished, where you will get everything ready for us.
The disciples-left, went to the city, and found everything just as Jesus had told them, and they prepared the Passover meal.
According to our local customs, we procure meat, pillau, fish, sweetmeats, curds, etc. for a good meal.
But for the Jews, their main dish were bread and meat.
And Jesus himself had instructed his disciples to prepare this meal.
The disciples prepared this meal with roasted lamb, bread baked without yeast and bitter herbs.
When it was evening, Jesus came with the twelve disciples.
While they were at table eating;
Jesus said, I tell you that one of you will betray me-one who is eating with me.
The disciples were upset and began to ask him, one after the other, Surely you don't mean me.
Jesus answered, It will be one of you twelve, one who dips his bread in the dish with me.
The Son of Man will die as he Scriptures say he will; but how terrible for that man who betrays the Son of Man!
It would have been better for that man if he had never been born!
Then the disciples completed the Passover meal before the death of Jesus.
There are certain feasts that we observe which was commanded by God himself.
It was God who delivered the Israelites from the oppression of the Egyptians.
So he commanded them to observe the Passover Feast to commemorate that event.
Our Lord Jesus Christ kept that Feast with his disciples even though he is the Son of God.
This expressed his obedience to God.
We too have to obey the commandments and the Laws of God.
We too observe this Passover Feast on Good Friday in remembrance of Jesus's suffering and death on the Cross for our sins.
He has delivered us from the bondage of sin.
Through this meal Jesus Christ expressed his love for us.
We-too express our love for our neighbours and relatives by inviting them to meals on special occasions.
In this way we grow in our mutual relationship-a growth in the spirit of love, affection, fellow- feeling, compassion and cooperation.
The supper that Jesus had with his disciples before his death is the New Passover or the meal of salvation.
Christ has taught us to be obedient to God.
Through this meal Jesus showed his authentic love for his disciples.
In the same way, we too have to love all people- friends or enemies.
We have to treat our enemies as friends.
In order to avoid such happenings in our family and in the society, we have to learn to be patient, kind and friendly.
Jesus did this with his disciples.
We must obey God's orders and commandments.
We have to observe rules and regulations in our family, in the society, in school, college and in the state.
This will help us to become good persons.
Jesus knew that one of his disciples was going to betray him, yet he was patient so that there is no conflict among them.
We may fall into a similar situation which may disturb us Hence we should be careful that others faults do not become public.
Above all, we have love everyone equally-friend or foe.
The meal that Jesus had with his disciples the day before he died on the Cress is known as the Last Supper.
After this he never again had any meals with his twelve disciples on this earth: This was his last meal with them.
Jesus had often eaten together with his disciples; but his farewell meal was very significant in the history of the Church.
Through this meal he left us a great example.
Meals are usually are a matter of joy.
But at this meal that Jesus had, there was sorrow.
For he knew that his suffering would begin after this meal.
Even though there was sorrow at this meal, still through this meal Jesus made a New Covenant with man.
Through this meal he built a salvific bridge between man and God the Father.
Jesus was sorrowful, but for us this meal is a means of communion with the Father.
Everyone- the poor, the rich and the sinners can take part in this meal.
A sinner can repent for his sins, confess his sins and then take part in this meal.
Through this meal we are united with the Lord, and the bond between the Father and his children grows strong.
Now we will learn about how this meal was instituted.
In the previous lesson we came to know, how the disciples had made the arrangements for this meal.
In this lesson we will learn how Jesus Christ celebrated this meal.
When we sit down to eat as a family, some, of us like to sit next to our father, and others next to our mother.
Isn't it so?
This is very natural.
In the same way, there was a quarrel among the disciples as to who would sit next to Jesus.
He wrapped a towel around his waist, and taking a bowl of water began to wash the feet of Ws disciples.
Simon Peter, however, refused to let Jesus wash his feet.
Then Jesus said to him, If I do not wash your feet, you will no longer be my disciple.
Then Peter, let him wash his feet.
After Jesus had washed their feet, he said to the disciples, you should do to one another what I have done to you.
I have set an example for you so that you will do just what I have done for you.
Blessed are you, if you do it for one another (John 13 : 1 -17).
Jesus actually wanted to teach them a lesson on humility.
After Jesus finished washing the feet of his disciples with great humility and meekness, he sat down at the table again.
Then he said to the disciples, I have earnestly desired to eat this passover with you before I suffer.
He took bread and when he had given thanks he broke it and gave it to them saying, Take and eat it;
this is my body which will be given up for you.
Then he took a cup filled with wine, gave thanks to God, and gave it to them saying.
Drink it, all of you.
This is my blood, which seals God's convenant, my blood poured out for many for the forgiveness of sins.
Do this in memory of me.
Then Jesus said to them, You will all fall away because of me.
For it is written in the Scriptures, `The flock of the sheep will be scattered (Zech.
But after I am raised to life, I will go to Galilee ahead of you.
Peter spoke up and said to Jesus, I will never leave you, even though all the rest do.
Jesus said to Peter, I tell you that before the cock crows tonight, you will say three times that you do not know me.
Peter answered, I will never say that, even if I have to die with you.
And all the other disciples said the same thing.
By nature human beings possess some qualities.
These qualities find expression in their behaviour and work.
These qualities need to be developed.
One needs ; to practice or exercise these qualities in order to develop their full potential.
If I do not use the qualities that I have, then they cannot be expressed well by any means.
I may have intelligence, but if I do not study, then I cannot do well in the examinations.
We can -develop our qualities by observing others develop theirs.
While living on this earth, Our Lord Jesus Christ trained up his disciples in his good qualities.
He used his qualities for the benefit of his disciples.
In this lesson we noticed how his affection, love, humility and meekness found expression.
Even though he was the Lord and Teacher, yet he washed the feet of his disciples and in this way set an example of humility.
Jesus has given us this meal as a sign or symbol.
Usually we understand by meal as food for the body; but Jesus gave us this meal as our spiritual food.
In order to save us from the slavery of sin Jesus died on the Cross; he made restitution for our sins.
He wants that if we should ever fall into sin, we should go to Confession and experience God's love as children of God.
After he broke the bread, he gave to all saying, Take and eat.; this is my body given for you.
It will be shed for all for the forgiveness of sins.
Do this in memory of me.
Jesus gave us his body and blood in the form of bread and wine for the forgiveness of our sins.
For the Christians, this is a matter of faith and experience.
Jesus Christ knew that there was a lack of faith in his disciples.
It is quite natural that when the leader of a group is persecuted, the members go away.
All the other disciples also said the same thing.
But Peter denied the Lord three times.
This shows that without God's power, no one can overcome his weakness.
Jesus said, Do to one another as I have done to you.
This means we have to humble and meek towards one another.
We should use all our talents and qualities for the good of ourselves, our family, our society and our country.
We have to uphold our Christian ideals and dedicate ourselves to the service of all.
God our loving Father, .you
have given me many talent and qualities.
Help me to use them for the good of myself and others.
Help me to take part in the Lord's Supper worthily and grow strong spiritually, morally and mentally.
This I pray in the name of Jesus Christ our Lord.
